Award.AwardTitle: GeoTech Consortium of Western New York: Get the GIST (Geospatial Information Science Technology) Certificate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Department of Labor considers the geospatial industry to be high growth (U.S. DOL, 2012). The GeoTech Consortium of Western New York (GTCWNY) is developing a geospatial certificate program to help support growing geospatial industry needs. The consortium focus is on program development and improvement by increasing the importance of geospatial technician education and the number of students with relevant geospatial and STEM competencies. It also focuses on professional development for educators, which has resulted in awareness of the geospatial industry at the high school level, and dual-credit opportunities for high school students. Led by Monroe Community College (MCC) of the State University of New York, GTCWNY is bridging the gaps among high schools, our two-year college, and the local and regional geospatial industry. The consortium is composed of Monroe Community College, three school districts, Monroe County, New York Geographic Alliance, Geographic Information Sharing-Special Interest Group, Northeast Area Development GIS Scholars, and a major geospatial corporation. With over 40 regional geospatial companies/agencies, GTCWNY serves industry demand and has an impact on STEM education. GTCWNY is combining leveraged courses from the GeoTech Center with current MCC courses to create a geospatial certificate program. The new courses are being aligned with the new Geospatial Technology Competency Model (GTCM) 2014 and the GeoTech Center Course Content Tool. The GTCWNY Geospatial Information Science Technology (GIST) Advisory Board is identifying local and regional employment skills, allowing GTCWNY to modify the geospatial courses to regional industry needs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite advances in geospatial technology and increasing job demand, few western New York high school and college students are aware of the employment potential in geospatial technology.  Geospatial technology refers to digital mapping or the integration of Geospatial Information Science and Technology (GIST), remote sensing (e.g., satellite or drone imagery), and Global Positioning System.  With support from the National Science Foundation Advanced Technological Education program, Monroe Community College (MCC) of the State University of New York built a geospatial career pipeline between three local high schools, the new MCC GIST (Geospatial Information Science and Technology) Certificate program, 'Get the GIST,' and the local and regional geospatial workforce.  The program offered professional development to 18 high school teachers as they implemented a GIS activity into their classrooms (2015-2018).  Four teachers were able to offer the dual enrollment introductory GIST course over the project period, with 7 sections offered.  As a result of these new dual enrollment opportunities, students will leave school with an awareness of GIST and upon enrolling MCC, will have a head start on earning the GIST certificate.

In only its second year, thirty students have been or are enrolled in the GIST program.  Student enrollment in introductory GIST has now more than doubled, growing from 45 in 2014-15, to 114 in 2016-17, and to 124 in 2018-19.  The MCC NSF ATE Get the GIST project received recognition in the National Science Foundation's Advanced Technological Impacts for this significant increase in enrollment.

As a part of the program, three new courses were developed and were aligned to local and industry needs: Cartography; Spatial Analysis and GIS; and a Capstone Course in Geospatial Technology.  The Capstone Course in Geospatial Technology offered multiple internships to students, growing opportunities from one internship in 2016-17 to eight in 2018-19.  Organizations offering internships ranged from rural New York townships to the not-for-profit Water for South Sudan and a university in Cartagena, Colombia. 

Principal investigators Jonathon Little and Heather Pierce of Monroe Community College presented at various local, state, and national conferences, to describe the MCC GIST curriculum and to expand awareness of its program.  Numerous high schools in the greater Rochester area have reached out to the PIs to learn how to bring geospatial technology to their school district.  After viewing presentations at a conference, industry professionals enrolled and are completing the GIST Certificate program to improve their GIST skills.  Collaboration within New York state GIST community college educators has increased. 

Select presentations include:

  • Building a GIST Certificate in Western New York (New York State GIS Association conference, Lake Placid, NY)
  • GeoTech Consortium of Western New York Exhibitor Booth (Geographic Information Sharing / Special Interest Group, Pittsford, NY)
  • Building a Geospatial Pipeline in Western New York (GeoEd, Louisville, KY)
  • Motivating the Unmotivated: Exciting students with GIS (Esri's Educators conference, San Diego, California)
  • Phycocyanin detection using Landsat TM imagery (remote sensing) for the nearshore of Lake Ontario, using methodology developed for the early detection of cyanobacteria in Maumee Bay, Ohio (Scholars' Day at MCC, Rochester, NY)
  • Expanding Geospatial Opportunities for High School and Community College Students in Western NY (HI-TEC, Pittsburgh, PA)
  • Building a Geospatial Career Pipeline: Connecting High Schools, Community College, and the Geospatial Workforce (Association of American Geographers, Boston, MA) 

Several unexpected student and faculty opportunities developed as a result of the GIST program.  A student-led mapping club began in 2017 and recently was recognized by MCC's Excellence in Innovation Award for its humanitarian mapping events, with over 80 participants.
Principal Investigator Little was selected to participate in the ATE Mentor-Connect "Moving Up" Mentoring program.  He taught geospatial technology in Kazakhstan as a Fulbright Specialist; and currently serves as the National Geographic steward for New York State

With development of a geospatial pipeline among local and regional high schools, the college, and industry, creation of new courses, and engagement with local organizations, the GIST program is starting to meet local and regional GIS industry needs.  Within the second complete year of the program, at least twelve students have gained employment (with EagleView and National Guard, Esri, Town of Ontario, Town of Greece, Genesee River Watch, and Solar).  Some recent graduates plan to transfer to a four year university.
